Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 78c9020305038b7974b4737c9b1d0b4afb9740f2

As Lakshmi points out, this whole patch is just extending lambdas that are already too long (with the exception of the one that's one line).  If some amount of refactoring needs to take place, so be it.
I've refactored those areas.
Non trivial lambda.
Done
Non trivial lambda.
Done
Non trivial lambda.
Done
Looking much better.  One minor thing about error handling that needs fixed then this can probably go.
Callback should be passed by non const &&

Using non-const && callback conflicts if the caller uses std::bind_front().

```

| ../../../../../../../../../bmcweb/redfish-core/lib/fabric_adapters.hpp: In function 'void redfish::getValidFabricAdapterPath(..., 
std::function<void(const boost::system::error_code&,..)>&&)':
| ../../../../../../../../../bmcweb/redfish-core/lib/fabric_adapters.hpp:240:24: error: invalid initialization of reference of type 

'std::function<void(const boost::system::error_code&, .... >&)>&&' 
from expression of type 
'std::_Bind_front_t<void (&)(
...
 std::function<void(const boost::system::error_code&, ...>&)> >'
|   240 |         std::bind_front(afterGetValidFabricAdapterPath, adapterId, std::move(callback)));

```

Even with the normal lambda, we can keep `const` would be needed.
So, I'm going to switch it to 
```
    const std::function<void(const boost::system::error_code&,
                             const std::string& fabricAdapterPath,
                             const std::string& serviceName)>&& callback,
```
and call it inside lambda.

I think - `const std::function<>&& callback` seems covering more situations than without `const`.

It turns out - CI does not accept it.

```
clang-tidy-17 -export-fixes /tmp/tmp63k1ly_5/tmpn25losy6.yaml -p=/data0/jenkins/workspace/ci-repository/openbmc/bmcweb/build31w48z5a -quiet /data0/jenkins/workspace/ci-repository/openbmc/bmcweb/src/webserver_main.cpp
../redfish-core/lib/fabric_adapters.hpp:242:51: error: std::move of the const variable 'callback' has no effect or make the variable non-const [performance-move-const-arg,-warnings-as-errors]
  242 |         afterGetValidFabricAdapterPath(adapterId, std::move(callback), ec2,
      |                                                   ^
../redfish-core/lib/fabric_adapters.hpp:191:65: note: consider changing the 2nd parameter of 'afterGetValidFabricAdapterPath' from 'const std::function<void (const boost::system::error_code &, const std::string &, const std::string &)> &&' (aka 'const function<void (const boost::system::error_code &, const basic_string<char> &, const basic_string<char> &)> &&') to 'const std::function<void (const boost::system::error_code &, const std::string &, const std::string &)> &'
  191 |                              const std::string& serviceName)>&& callback,
      |                                                                 ^
239345 warnings generated.
Applying fixes …

```

CI suggests to use 
```
const std::function<void (const boost::system::error_code &, const std::string &, const std::string &)>& callback
```

So, I changed the code as such and use `std::move(callback)` at caller.

Then just make it a value.  If we have to make a copy, lets make it explicit.


There's a bug somewhere;  We do this same pattern other places, so I would expect it to work, but sure, it's not going to be a major problem here.

There are a few places that use `const std::function<...>& callback` as a parameter.

https://github.com/search?q=repo%3Aopenbmc%2Fbmcweb+%22%3E%26+callback%22&type=code

I think they were done as such due to same reasons.

Here, as you suggested, I make it as a value

Making it as value causes CI failure.

```
../redfish-core/lib/fabric_adapters.hpp:192:9: error: the parameter 'callback' is copied for each invocation but only used as a const reference; consider making it a const reference [performance-unnecessary-value-param,-warnings-as-errors]
  189 |     std::function<void(const boost::system::error_code&,
      |     const 
  190 |                        const std::string& fabricAdapterPath,
  191 |                        const std::string& serviceName)>
      |                                                        
      |                                                        &
  192 |         callback,
      |         ^
239357 warnings generated.
```

So, I think we would need to use `const std::function<...>& callback`

Making it a value causes CI failure.

```
../redfish-core/lib/fabric_adapters.hpp:192:9: error: the parameter 'callback' is copied for each invocation but only used as a const reference; consider making it a const reference [performance-unnecessary-value-param,-warnings-as-errors]
  189 |     std::function<void(const boost::system::error_code&,
      |     const 
  190 |                        const std::string& fabricAdapterPath,
  191 |                        const std::string& serviceName)>
      |                                                        
      |                                                        &
  192 |         callback,
      |         ^
239357 warnings generated.
....


-    std::function<void(const boost::system::error_code&,
-                       const std::string& fabricAdapterPath,
-                       const std::string& serviceName)>
-        callback,
+    const std::function<void(const boost::system::error_code&,
+                             const std::string& fabricAdapterPath,
+                             const std::string& serviceName)>& callback,
```

So, I need to go back to `const std::function<...>& callback`.
ACK
Thank you for making an attempt.
FYI, this pattern shows up a lot in the codebase.  Realistically there should be a mapper call that can do this for us, rather than bmcweb trying to invent a new version for every possible type.

It would be great if mapper functions that match with `id` (not `path`). With it,  many things can be simplified.
For example, to use many dbus/mapper calls, we first need to search `path` from the given `id`.  As the result, we may almost always to call `getSubTree()` and compare each path with `id`.

For now, we may need to still walk thru the subtree to find the matching path.
std::move()
Changed to match with afterGetValidFabricAdapterPath() using lambda

Does this actually need checked?  If either of these are true, then there should be an error code set and handled on line 249.

I don't see how we can hit this code.
same as above.
Yes, as described in https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/69499/comment/662c4f6c_69359b5c/

What about    const std::string& adapterId, const std::string& systemName, ? 
If you have these, I feel they should be correct. You could just remove.

Yes, we can remove this comment line.

In addition, checking `(systemName != "system")` from `getValidFabricAdapterPath` is better moved to the caller route handler like the other cases.  This will prevent the duplicate `systemName` checkings if `getValidFabricAdapterPath()` are used other cases.
Done
